byline.original: By BEN PROTESS and DANIELLE IVORY

abstract: Federal prosecutors are set to impose $1 billion fine on General Motors for failing to disclose safety defect tied to deaths of 124 people; fine is lower than anticipated, reflecting company's willingness to cooperate with investigation; individual employees are not expected to face indictment because of new Justice Dept rules governing criminal charges against corporate employees.
lead_paragraph: The deal would be in the form of a deferred-prosecution agreement, and include a penalty just under $1 billion. But no G.M. employees are expected to be indicted.

headline.main: U.S. Said to Have Settled With G.M. Over Deadly Defect
headline.print_headline: U.S. Settlement Seen in Inquiry Into G.M. Defect

snippet: The deal would be in the form of a deferred-prosecution agreement, and include a penalty just under $1 billion. But no G.M. employees are expected to be indicted.
